titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Bernard Greenberg Collection, 1951-1988 AIS.2010.09
titlestmt.author: Zachary Brodt.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 09:38:00 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Bernard Greenberg Collection
did.abstract: Bernard Greenberg worked for the United Steelworkers of America's Department of Pensions and Insurance. This collection contains reports regarding health care and insurance, as well as applications of companies to be approved as health service agencies in Pennsylvania.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Zachary Brodt in July 2010.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Bernard Greenberg Collection, 1951-1988, AIS.2010.09, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Bernard Greenberg Collection, 1951-1988, AIS.2010.09, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Bernard Greenberg was an economist for the United Steelworkers of America's Department of Pensions and Insurance. He began working for the union in 1949 and also served as the assistant director of benefits and pensions. Greenberg was a member of the Health Systems Agency of Southwestern Pennsylvania Review Committee during the 1980s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection contains reports regarding health care and insurance. Also included are applications of companies to be approved as health service agencies according to Pennsylvania law. Studies on Soviet and American health care providers are also present, as well as conference proceedings.
